revision.text:
{{Infobox port | name =Al Duqm Port & Drydock {{Location map|Oman|label=Al Duqm
Port
& Drydock |marksize=6|mark=Red_pog.svg |lat_dir=N|lat_deg=19|lat_min=40|lat_sec=7 |lon_dir=E|lon_deg=57|lon_min=42|lon_sec=0 |position=right|width=200|float=right |caption=Location in Oman}} | country ={{flag|Oman}} | location =[[Duqm]], [[Al Wusta Region (Oman)|Al Wusta Region]] | coordinates ={{Coord|19|40|7|N|57|42|0|E|type:landmark_region:OM|display=inline,title}} | opened = 2013| operated = Oman Drydock Company, S.A.O.C. | owner = Government of Oman| type = Port and Drydock| sizewater = | sizeland = | size = | berths = | wharfs = | piers = | employees = | leadershiptitle = | leader = | blankdetailstitle1 = | blankdetails1 = | blankdetailstitle2 = | blankdetails2 = | blankdetailstitle3 = | blankdetails3 = | arrivals = | cargotonnage = | containervolume = | cargovalue = | passengertraffic = | revenue = 1.5 bl US Dollar| profit = | blankstatstitle1 = | blankstats1 = | blankstatstitle2 = | blankstats2 = | blankstatstitle3 = | blankstats3 = | website = http://www.omandrydock.com/ }} '''Al Duqm Port & Drydock''' is a [[seaport]] located in [[Oman]]. The port is equipped with a Ship Repair Yard & [[Drydock]] facility, which is the first of its kind in Oman. Control of the port was transferred to the [[Ministry of Transport and Communications (Oman)|Ministry of Transport and Communications]] in May 2012. The port authority is the [[Port of Duqm Company]], S.A.O.C., who manage the port. [[Oman Drydock Company]] (ODC) have run the ship repair yard since 2013; primarily for the overhaul and conversion of large commercial vessels. In 2017 ODC and [[Babcock International Group]] started [[Duqm Naval Dockyard]] (DND), focusing on the expansion of the port's capability into the support of military forces operating in the region.{{cite web |url=http://www.omanobserver.om/new-oman-duqm-naval-dockyard-set-april-launch|title=New Oman Duqm Naval Dockyard set for April launch|publisher=OEPPA}} ==International access== In August 2017, Oman and the United Kingdom signed a [[memorandum of understanding]] allowing th [[Royal Navy]] access to the port facilities of Duqm.{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-gets-access-to-strategic-oman-port-for-military-use-chabahar-gwadar-in-sight-5061573/ |publisher=''[[Indian Express]]'' |title=India gets access to strategic Oman port Duqm for military use, Chabahar-Gwadar in sight |first=Shubhajit |last=Roy |date=February 13, 2018}} In February 2018, India announced that it had secured access to the facilities at Duqm for the [[Indian Air Force]] and the [[Indian Navy]]. Duqm had previously served as a port for the [[INS Mumbai|INS ''Mumbai'']]. ==See Also== * http://www.omandrydock.com/ * https://www.portduqm.com/About/Port-Authority.html * http://www.omanobserver.om/new-oman-duqm-naval-dockyard-set-april-launch/ ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Al Duqm Port and Drydock}} [[Category:Transport in Oman]] [[Category:Ports and harbours in Asia]] {{Oman-transport-stub}}

{{Infobox song | name = Are You Sure? | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[The Allisons]] | album = | B-side = There's One Thing More | released = [[1961 in music|February 1961]] | format = | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | length = {{Duration|m=2|s=05}} | label = [[London Records]] 1977 | writer = John Allison, Bob Allison | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = Words | next_year = 1961 }} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} "Are You Sure?" | image = | caption = | year = 1961 | country = United Kingdom | artist = [[The Allisons]] | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[John Alford (singer)|John Allison]], [[Bob Allison]] | lyricist = [[John Alford (singer)|John Allison]], [[Bob Allison]] | conductor = [[Harry Robinson (musician)|Harry Robinson]] | place = 2nd | points = 24 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1961uk from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Looking High, High, High | prev_link = Looking High, High, High | next = Ring-A-Ding Girl | next_link = Ring-A-Ding Girl }} '''"Are You Sure?"''' is a song by [[United Kingdom|British]] pop duo [[The Allisons]], that represented the United Kingdom at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1961]], performed in [[English language|English]]. The song was performed 15th on the night of the contest, held on 18 March 1961, following [[Luxembourg]]'s [[Jean-Claude Pascal]] with "[[Nous les amoureux]]", and preceding [[Italy]]'s [[Betty Curtis]] with "[[Al di là]]". The song received 24 points, placing 2nd in a field of 16, the third consecutive second place Eurovision finish for the UK for whom two subsequent Eurovision entrants would also be second-place finishers before "[[Puppet on a String]]" by [[Sandie Shaw]] would give the UK its first Eurovision victory at [[Eurovision Song Contest 1967|Eurovision 1967]]. "Are You Sure?" was also the first UK Eurovision entrant to become a Top Ten hit reaching #2 UK, the best chart showing for a UK Eurovision entrant until "Puppet on a String" by Sandie Shaw reached #1 in 1967. The song was succeeded as the [[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest|UK representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1962|1962 Contest]] by [[Ronnie Carroll]] with "[[Ring-A-Ding Girl]]". The lyrics are memorable for a possibly unique example of the bizarre grammatical error "Comes tomorrow, you won't want me". ==Chart performance== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1961) !Peak
position |- |United Kingdom (''[[Record Retailer]]'') | style="text-align:center;"|2{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/artist/_/allisons/|title=Artist Chart History Details: Allisons|publisher=[[The Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=8 August 2010}} |- |United Kingdom (''[[List of NME number-one singles from the 1960s|NME]]'') | style="text-align:center;"|1{{cite book|last3=Osborne|first3=Roger|first=Dafydd|last=Rees|first2=Barry|last2=Lazell|title=Forty Years of "NME" Charts|edition=2nd|year=1995|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Pan Macmillan]]|isbn=0-7522-0829-2|page=99}} |- |United Kingdom ([[List of Record Mirror number-one singles|''Record Mirror'']]) | style="text-align:center;"|1{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Alan |title=Every No.1 in the 1960s is listed from all the nine different magazine charts! |url=http://www.davemcaleer.com/page22.htm |work=[[Dave McAleer]]'s website |accessdate=4 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012125528/http://www.davemcaleer.com/page22.htm |archivedate=12 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1961}} {{Eurovision (UK)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Are You Sure?}} [[Category:1961 singles]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1961]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:London Records singles]] [[Category:Fontana Records singles]] [[Category:1961 songs]] {{1960s-single-stub}} {{UK-stub}}

{{Infobox language family |name=Boan |altname=Ababuan |region=[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Southern Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone C|Zones C–D]]) |child1=[[Bati–Angba languages|Bati–Angba]] (Bwa) |child2=[[Komo–Bira languages|Komo–Bira]] |glotto=abab1240 |glottorefname=Ababuan }}
'''Boan''' (Buan, ''Ababuan'') is a proposed intermediate group of [[Bantu languages]] coded Zones C and D in Guthrie's classification.<ref>McMaster, Mary Allen. 1988. ''Patterns of Interaction: A comparative ethnolinguistic perspective on the Uele region of Zaïre ca. 500 A.D. to 1900 A.D.'' Los Angeles: University of California. 346.</ref> There are three branches:
*''[[Komo language (Bantu)|Komo]]'' (D20) *''[[Bali language (Congo)|Bali]]'' (D20), ?[[Beeke language|Beeke]] *Bomokandian (the various [[Bati–Angba languages|Bwa]] and [[Komo–Bira languages|Biran]] languages) **[[Biran languages|Biran]] (Bira–Amba) (D22, D30) **''[[Homa language|Homa]] (Ngenda)'' (D40) **''[[Lika language|Lika]]'' (D20) **[[Bati–Angba languages|Bati–Angba]] (Bwa) (C40)
Beeke is an erstwhile member of the [[Nyali languages|Nyali]] cluster that seems to be closest to Bali.
In the ''Glottolog'' 2.3 classification, several additional, poorly attested languages are included as being closest to Homa/Ngenda:
*''[[Bali language (Congo)|Bali]]'' (D20) *Old Bomokandian **[[Komo–Bira languages|Komoic]] (Biran, incl. Komo) **[[Bati–Angba languages|Middle Bomokandian]] (Lika & Bati–Angba) **Ngbele–Ngenda ***Extreme-north Vestigial-suffix Bantu: [[Kari language (Democratic Republic of Congo)|Kari]], [[Ngbee language|Ngbee]], [[Nyanga-li language|Nyanga-li]] (Gbati-ri) ***Ngendan ****[[Homa language|Homa]], [[Ngbinda language|Ngbinda]], ?[[Boguru language|Boguru]], ?[[Bodo language (Central African Republic)|Bodo]] (perhaps instead [[Lebonya languages|Lebonya]])
== References == <references />
{{Narrow Bantu languages}} [[Category:Boan languages| ]]
{{Bantu-lang-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Boao Forum for Asia
{{nobold|博鳌亚洲论坛}} |image = Bo'ao Forum for Asia - logo 01.jpg |size = 250px |formation = 2001 |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = Forum |headquarters = [[Bo'ao]], [[Hainan]], China
[[Beijing]] (Secretariat) |region_served = Asia |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20130403015310/http://english.boaoforum.org/ www.boaoforum.org] |}} The '''Boao Forum for Asia''' ('''BFA'''; {{zh|c=博鳌亚洲论坛|p=Bó'áo Yàzhōu Lùntán}}) is a non-profit organisation that hosts high-level forums for leaders from government, business and academia in [[Asia]] and other continents to share their vision on the most pressing issues in this dynamic region and the world at large. BFA is modelled on the [[World Economic Forum]] held annually in [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]]. Its fixed address is in [[Bo'ao]], [[Hainan]] province, [[China]], although the Secretariat is based in [[Beijing]]. The forum, sometimes known as the “Asian Davos”, takes its name from the town of Boao, located in China’s southern Hainan province, which has been the permanent venue for its annual conference since 2002.Lavers, Georgina, [http://vision.ae/articles/global_integration_dubai_to_host_boao_forum_for_asia "Global integration: Dubai to host Boao Forum for Asia"], ''[[Vision (magazine)|Vision]]'', June 2014. The Forum is committed to promoting regional economic integration and bringing Asian countries even closer to their development goals. Initiated in 1998 by [[Fidel V. Ramos]], former President of the Philippines, [[Bob Hawke]], former Prime Minister of Australia, and [[Morihiro Hosokawa]], former Prime Minister of Japan, the Boao Forum for Asia was formally inaugurated in February 2001. The founding of the BFA was driven by the People's Republic of China and founded by 26 [[Asia]]n and [[Australasia]]n states on 27 February 2001. The organisation held its first meeting from 12–13 April 2002. Discussions at the BFA focus on economics, integration, cooperation, society and the environment. In the past the forum also addressed China's entry into the [[World Trade Organization]], as well as [[1997 Asian Financial Crisis|Southeast Asia's economic crisis during the 1990s]]. The geopolitical strategy '[[China's peaceful rise]]' was a topic of discussion for the forum in 2004. In addition to its annual meeting, the BFA also sponsors other forums and meetings related to Asian issues. == 2008 == The Boao Forum For Asia Annual Conference 2008 was held on 10–13 April 2008. It was attended by heads of government from countries including [[Australia]], [[Pakistan]], [[Norway]] and [[Kazakhstan]]. It also saw the historic meeting of [[Taiwan]]'s [[Republic of China]] Vice President-elect [[Vincent Siew]], with [[People's Republic of China]] president [[Hu Jintao]].[http://english.cri.cn/4026/2008/04/12/1481@344920.htm 2008 Boao Forum for Asia to Kick Off in China CRI News 2008-04-12 (extracted 2018-04-17)] [https://www.reuters.com/news/picture/taiwan-vp-elect-says-china-agrees-to-off-idUSTP23117620080414 Taiwan VP-elect says China agrees to official talks REUTERS 2008-04-14 (extracted 2018-04-17)] ==2009== The 2009 forum was held in Boao, Hainan, from 17-19 April, 2009. The theme was "Asia: Managing Beyond Crisis". http://en.people.cn/90002/96912/index.html Boao Forum for Asia 2009], People's Daily Online ==2010== The 2010 forum was held in Boao, Hainan, from 9-11 April, 2010. The theme was "Green Recovery: Asia’s Realistic Choice for Sustainable Growth". [http://www.cctv.com/english/special/boao2010/homepage/index.shtml 2010 Boao Forum For Asia], cctv.com == 2011 == [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in China 15 April 2011-7.jpeg|thumb|Boao Forum for Asia 2011]] The Energy, Resources & Sustainable Development Conference for the organisation was held in [[Perth, Western Australia]], [[Australia]] between the 11 and 12 July 2011.{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=Amanda|title=Keep China close, says Kerry Stokes|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/keep-china-closesays-stokes/story-e6frg8zx-1226093398209|publisher=The Australian|accessdate=13 July 2011|date=July 13, 2011}} {{cite web|last=Lady. Zhong Press officer of the Secretariat of Boao Forum for Asia|title=Boao Forum|url=http://www.boaoforum.org/CPF/News_ShowContent-en.asp?Seq=2005001177|work=Latest Reports|publisher=BFA|accessdate=13 July 2011}} The conferences brought together business, industry and political leaders in the region to discuss energy and resource security, development and trade. [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Australia)|Australian Foreign Minister]] [[Kevin Rudd]] stated China will invest US 1 trillion dollars abroad and Australia is in a good position to attract capital to develop new mines, infrastructure to service China's insatiable appetite for energy and resources. {{cite news|last=AAP|title=Rudd says China offers big opportunities|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/rudd-says-china-offers-big-opportunities-20110711-1ha8z.html|work=AAP|publisher=news.smh.com.au|accessdate=13 July 2011|date=July 11, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Business Spectator Pty Ltd.|title=Australia key to China investment: report|url=http://www.businessspectator.com.au/bs.nsf/Article/Australia-key-to-China-investment-report-pd20110712-JPPB7?OpenDocument|publisher=Business Spectator Pty Ltd.|accessdate=13 July 2011|date=13 Jul 2011}} Rudd also indicated while Chinese capital is essential for Australia's economic future, China needs to do more in relaxing foreign investment rules for Australian companies such as restrictions on types of businesses, equity restrictions and branch or representative office caps.{{cite news|last=O'Brien|first=Amanda|title=Rudd hits back at China over protectionism|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/rudd-hits-back-at-china-over-protectionism/story-fn59niix-1226092655880|publisher=The Australian|accessdate=13 July 2011|date=July 12, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Emery|first=Kate|title='Integrate' with China or dip out|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/integrate-with-china-or-dip-out-stokes-warns-20110712-1hc9u.html|work=The West Australian|publisher=www.smh.com.au|accessdate=13 July 2011|date=13 July 2011}} == 2013 == This year forum was held from April 6th to 8th in Hainan Province. [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/special/boao2013/index.htm Boao Forum for Asia annual conference 2013 Xinhau Net 2013-04-08 Retrieved 2018-04-17 [[Bill Gates]], [[George Soros]] and [[Christine Lagarde]] attended.{{cite web|url=http://english.boaoforum.org/mtzxxwzxen/6690.jhtml|title=Bill Gates, Soros and Lagarde Confirm Attendance at Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference 2013|publisher=Boao Forum for Asia|accessdate=2 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130402083241/http://english.boaoforum.org/mtzxxwzxen/6690.jhtml|archivedate=2 April 2013|df=}} [[Xi Jinping]] delivered the keynote address.[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/boao2013/2013-04/08/content_16382178.htm "Xi's speech at Boao draws positive comments"], ''chinadaily.com.cn'', 2013-04-08. Retrieved 2013-05-24. This year focus was on "Restructuring".[ http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2013-04/05/content_16377814.htm 2013 Boao Forum to focus on 'restructuring', China Daily 2013-04-05 Retrieved 2018-04-17] ==2014== The 2014 forum was held in Hainan, from 8-11 April, 2014, with the official opening address from Chinese premier [[Li Keqiang]] on 10 April.[http://www.boaoforum.org/annual2014/10815.jhtml "Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference 2014" (in Chinese)], ''boaoforum.org'', April 8, 2014. The theme of the forum was "Asia's New Future: Identifying New Growth Drivers".[http://english.boaoforum.org/mtzxxwzxen/11494.jhtml Boao Forum Information Centre Jan 9, 2014] Indian business tycoon Ratan Tata was appointed as a member of the Board of Boao Forum. The post is a rare distinction for an Indian in the Chinese government-backed influential body. [http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/ratan-tata-member-of-china-backed-boao-forum-114041001401_1.html Business Standard :Ratan Tata member of China-backed Boao Forum April 11, 2014] ==2015== Leaders or deputies from 16 countries, including [[Armenia]], [[Australia]], [[Austria]], [[China]], [[Indonesia]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Malaysia]], [[Nepal]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Qatar]], [[Russia]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Sweden]], [[Thailand]], [[Uganda]], and [[Zambia]], attended the forum held from March 26 to 29. The theme of this year forum is "community of shared destiny". [http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/boao2015/node_53000241.htm Boao Forum for Asia 2015 , China Daily 2018-04-23] ==2016== The 2016 forum was held in Hainan, from 22-25 March, 2016. Participants at the annual conference focused on Asia's New future: New Dynamics, New Vision and took part in panel discussions. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang made the keynote speech at the opening of the annual conference.[http://www.china.org.cn/business/node_7235918.htm Boao Forum for Asia 2016 China.org.cn 2018-04-23] ==2017== The 2017 forum was held from 23-26 March, 2017. Keynote speech was made by Chinese Vice Premier [[Zhang Gaoli]] at the opening plenary of the Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference 2017. [http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2017-03/27/c_136162062.htm Chinese Vice Premier Zhang Gaoli's keynote speech at opening plenary of Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference 2017], Xinhuanet.com 2017-03-27 The theme for the conference was "Globalization and Free Trade: The Asian Perspectives". ==2018== The Boao Forum for Asia 2018 was held between April 8th to 11th at Hainan Province, China. The theme of this year forum was "An Open and Innovative Asia for a World of Greater Prosperity".[http://english.boaoforum.org/en/index.html Boao Forum for Asia 2018 home page 2018-04-17] China president [[Xi Jinping]] gave the opening speech at the opening ceremony.[http://english.boaoforum.org/focus/38704.jhtml President Xi addresses opening ceremony of BFA annual conference 2018 2018-04-17] He said China will open up market including lowering tariffs on imported autos amid increasing trade tensions between US and China. [https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/09/chinese-president-xi-jinping-speaks-at-boao-forum-for-asia.html China's Xi announces plans to 'open' China, including lowering tariffs on imported autos 2018-04-09] ==See also== *[[World Economic Forum]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Boao Forum for Asia}} * {{official website|http://english.boaoforum.org/}} {{Hainan topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boao Forum For Asia}} [[Category:Hainan]] [[Category:Foreign relations of China]] [[Category:Think tanks based in China]] [[Category:Global economic conferences]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Bilateral relations|Bulgarian-Canada|Bulgaria|Canada}} '''Bulgaria–Canada relations''' refer to [[Interstate relations]] between [[Bulgaria]] and [[Canada]].
== Overview == [[File:Bulgaria, Ottawa2.JPG|thumb|right|Embassy of Bulgaria in Ottawa]] Canada's Ambassador in [[Bucharest]] is accredited to Bulgaria, while an Honorary Consulate in [[Sofia]] assists Canadian interests in Bulgaria.<ref>http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/romania-roumanie/offices-bureaux/consulate_sofia_consulat.aspx Office of the Honorary Consul of Canada to Bulgaria in Sofia</ref> Bulgaria has an embassy in [[Ottawa]] and a consulate-general in [[Toronto]].<ref>[http://www.bgembassy.ca/indexeng.htm Bulgarian embassy in Ottawa] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202174722/http://www.bgembassy.ca/indexeng.htm |date=2009-02-02 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bgconsultor.com/ Bulgarian consulate in Toronto]</ref> [[Bulgaria]]n-born [[Bulgarian Canadians|Canadian]] businessman, construction magnate and philanthropist [[Ignat Kaneff]] is the Honorary Consul of Bulgaria in Canada.<ref>[http://www.24chasa.bg/Article.asp?ArticleId=1588596 Игнат Канев: Дарих 2000 долара за болница и изведнъж станах "някой", в-к "24 часа", 15.10.2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106074810/http://www.24chasa.bg/Article.asp?ArticleId=1588596 |date=2013-11-06 }}</ref>
Canada and Bulgaria enjoy very good bilateral relations, highlighted by shared membership in [[la Francophonie]]. There is increasing trade and investment, effective military and security cooperation, and growing academic and cultural relations between the two countries.<ref>http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/romania-roumanie/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada_bulgaria-bulgarie.aspx?lang=eng Canada-Bulgaria Relations</ref>
Canada's Honorary Consul in [[Sofia]] plays an active role in fostering political, commercial and cultural relations between Canada and Bulgaria. His office offers consular support to Canadian citizens as well as Trade Commissioner Services and support in Bulgaria.<ref>http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/romania-roumanie/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada_bulgaria-bulgarie.aspx?lang=eng Canada-Bulgaria Relations</ref>
More than 30,000 [[Bulgarian Canadians|Canadians of Bulgarian origin]] live in Canada and have made unique and valuable contributions to Canada. Approximately 1,000 Canadians live permanently in Bulgaria and up to 15,000 Canadians visited Bulgaria in 2011.<ref>http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/romania-roumanie/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada_bulgaria-bulgarie.aspx?lang=eng Canada-Bulgaria Relations</ref>
== Trade relations == Bulgaria is one of Canada's largest merchandise trade partners in South East Europe with bilateral trade reaching $369.3 million in 2012. Canadian companies are important to Bulgaria's mining industry and are showing interest in the oil and gas sector in both onshore and offshore exploration. Business opportunities for Canadian companies exist in Bulgaria in telecommunications, airport services, electrical generation and agriculture.<ref>http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/romania-roumanie/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada_bulgaria-bulgarie.aspx?lang=eng Canada-Bulgaria Relations</ref>
== Bilateral treaties and agreements ==
* Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement, which was signed on March 3, 1999.<ref>http://www.fin.gc.ca/treaties-conventions/in_force--eng.asp Tax Treaties In Force</ref>
== See also == * [[Foreign relations of Bulgaria]] * [[Foreign relations of Canada]] * [[Canada–European Union relations]] * [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Foreign relations of Bulgaria}} {{Foreign relations of Canada}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bulgaria-Canada relations}} [[Category:Bulgaria–Canada relations| ]] [[Category:Bilateral relations of Bulgaria|Canada]] [[Category:Bilateral relations of Canada]]

See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. -->
'''CNV Public''' is a [[trade union]] affiliate of the [[Christelijk Nationaal Vakverbond]] in the [[Netherlands]]. It was formed in 1983 from the merger of the [[ARKA]], NCBO, and the [[NCVVV]].
CNV Public represents civil servants and healthcare workers in the Netherlands.
==External links== * [http://www.cnvpubliekezaak.nl/ CNV Public] website.
{{Portal|Organized labour}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}}
[[Image:Collette Lemieux 06.jpg|right|thumb|Collette Lemieux, co-chair of the Canadian Peace Alliance, speaking to an anti-war rally in Calgary she helped organize in 2007 as part of the ''Pan-Canadian Day of Action on Canada's military involvement in Afghanistan''.]]
'''The Canadian Peace Alliance / L'Alliance canadienne pour la paix''' (CPA/ACP) was a [[Canada|Canadian]] umbrella [[Peace movement|peace organization]] claiming more than 140 member groups. It was founded in 1985 but became inactive in 2017.
The Canadian Peace Alliance organized cross-Canada campaigns and actions; arranged political lobbying sessions between member groups and key political leaders in Ottawa; facilitated the development of strategies for the Canadian peace movement; and produced and distributed education and action materials.
The Canadian Peace Alliance's policy and campaign direction was determined by a bi-annual convention of member groups and by a geographically representative Steering Committee.
The Canadian Peace Alliance worked closely with the [[Canadian Labour Congress]].
==See also== *[[Ceasefire Canada]] *[[Canadian Peace Congress]]
== External links == *[https://www.facebook.com/CanadianPeaceAlliance/ The Canadian Peace Alliance / L'Alliance canadienne pour la paix] [[Category:Peace organizations]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080106203126/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=5a15f760-ae58-4765-bbc6-6541fdd59e3f Ottawa Citizen story on Cairo Anti-war Conference] *[http://www.acp-cpa.ca/ Canadian Peace Alliance - Canadian Political Parties and Political Interest Groups] - Web Archive created by University of Toronto Libraries

revision.text:
[[File:CEM-44-La-Chine-la-Tartarie-Chinoise-et-le-Thibet-1734-2568.jpg|thumb|400px|D’Anville’s map of China and Chinese Tartary created in 1734]]
'''Chinese Tartary''' (see also [[Tartary]]) is an archaic geographical term used especially during the time of the [[Qing Dynasty]]. The term was used as early as 1734 on a map created by the French geographer and cartographer [[Jean Baptiste Bourguignon d’Anville]] (1697–1782) who published the map in the ''Nouvel atlas de la Chine, de la Tartarie Chinoise et du Thibet'' (New atlas of China, Chinese Tartary, and Tibet) in 1738 (refer to the date of 1734 that appears on the map). D’Anville’s map was based on work ordered by the Emperor of China and conducted by Chinese under the supervision of the Jesuits.<ref name=wdi>{{cite web|website=World Digital Library|title=New atlas of China, Chinese Tartary, and Tibet|url=https://www.wdl.org/en/item/167/}}</ref> Also published in 1738 was ''A description of the empire of China and Chinese-Tartary together with the kingdoms of Korea, and Tibet'' by Father [[Jean-Baptiste Du Halde]].<ref>[https://archive.org/details/descriptionofemp00duha A description of the empire of China and Chinese-Tartary together with the kingdoms of Korea, and Tibet] by [[Jean-Baptiste Du Halde]], Volume 2 (1738).</ref> He went on to write in 1741 ''The General History of China Containing a Geographical, Historical, Chronological, Political and Physical Description of the Empire of China, Chinese-Tartary, Corea and Thibet''.<ref> {https://archive.org/details/generalhistoryc02haldgoog ''The General History of China: Containing a Geographical, Historical, Chronological, Political and Physical Description of the Empire of China, Chinese-Tartary, Corea and Thibet''] by [[Jean-Baptiste Du Halde]], Volume 2 (1736).</ref> Modern areas today that were described by their work as falling within Chinese Tartary included: *[[Xinjiang]] *[[Mongolia]] *[[Manchuria]] *[[Qinghai]] (kokonor or Ho-Ho-Nor)
Its geographical boundaries are defined in ''A Geographical Dictionary Or Universal Gazetteer''.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Geographical Dictionary Or Universal Gazetteer, Ancient and Modern, Volume 2|author=Joseph Emerson Worcester|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=vXM9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA703}}</ref>
==Further reading== * "Chinese Tartary." ''The Asiatic journal and monthly register for British and foreign India, China and Australasia, Volume 20''. Allen, 1836. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=f8tGAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA292 292].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of Asia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox settlement <!-- See Template:Infobox settlement for additional fields and descriptions --> | name = Cockpit Country | native_name = | native_name_lang = | settlement_type = Geographical Region | image_skyline = Cockpit Country.jpg | imagesize = 250px | image_alt = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = Jamaica | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|18.295209|-77.695313|display=inline}} | coor_pinpoint = | coordinates_footnotes = | subdivision_type = [[Country]] | subdivision_name = [[Jamaica]] | subdivision_type1 = [[Parish]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Trelawny Parish|Trelawny]] | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | established_title = | established_date = | named_for = Topology reminiscent of the shape of [[cock fighting]] dens. | total_type = | unit_pref = | area_magnitude = | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = | area_total_sq_mi = | area_total_dunam = | area_land_km2 = | area_land_sq_mi = | area_water_km2 = | area_water_sq_mi = | area_water_percent = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_ft = | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_as_of = | population_density_km2 = | population_density_sq_mi= | population_est = | pop_est_as_of = | population_demonym = | population_note = | timezone1 = EST | utc_offset1 = -5 | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code_type = | area_code = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Cockpit Country''' is an area in [[Trelawny Parish|Trelawny]] and [[Saint Elizabeth Parish|Saint Elizabeth]] parishes in [[Jamaica]]. The land is marked by steep-sided hollows, as much as {{convert|120|m|ft}} deep in places, which are separated by conical hills and ridges. [[Maroon (people)|Maroon]]s who had escaped from plantations used the difficult territory for its natural defenses to develop communities outside the control of [[Spanish Empire|Spanish]] or [[British Empire|British]] [[colonialism|colonists]]. Since 1739 it has been the center of [[Accompong]], an indigenous Maroon community that still has a certain recognized autonomy under the independent Jamaican government.
==Geography== On the north, the main defining feature is the fault-based "Escarpment", a long ridge that extends from Flagstaff in the west, through Windsor in the centre, to Campbells and the start of the Barbecue Bottom Road (B10). The Barbecue Bottom Road, which runs north-south, high along the side of a deep, fault-based valley in the east, is the only drivable route across the Cockpit Country. Walkers and riders can use two old, historical trails cross further west, the Troy Trail, and the Quick Step Trail. As of 2006 they are seldom used and difficult to find.
In the southwest, near Quick Step, is the district known as the "Land of Look Behind." It was so named because Spanish horsemen venturing into this region of hostile escaped slaves were said to have ridden two to a mount, one rider facing to the rear to keep a precautionary watch against ambush.
Where the ridges between sinkholes in the plateau area have dissolved, flat-bottomed basins or valleys have been formed that are filled with [[terra rossa (soil)|terra rosa]] soils, some of the most productive on the island. The largest basin is the Vale of Clarendon, {{convert|80|km|mi}} long and {{convert|32|km|mi}} wide. Queen of Spains Valley, [[Nassau Valley]], and Cave Valley were formed by the same process.
Shallow caves, known locally as cockpits (based on pits used for [[cockfights]]), are particularly common around the hamlet of Quick Step, reaching a density of 15 per km<sup>2</sup>.<ref>Jamaica Underground: The Caves, Sinkholes and Underground Rivers of the Island, by Alan Fincham (page 31). </ref> Noteworthy caves include Marta Tick Cave<ref>http://www.jamaicancaves.org/martatick.htm</ref> and Minocal's Glory Hole<ref>http://www.jamaicancaves.org/minocals_050115.htm</ref>. Ecotourism has been proposed for the hamlet of Quick Step, at the end of the road into the heart of Cockpit County.<ref>http://www.cockpitcountry.com/Quickstep.html</ref>
==Environment== The Cockpit Country is Jamaica's largest remaining contiguous [[rainforest]]. In 1979 an unpublished paper proposed preserving the area as a National Park.<ref>Cotterell "The Proposed Development of the Cockpit Country." Unpublished. NRCD, Kingston, Jamaica. 1979.</ref> In 1994 the geographer [[Alan Eyre]]<ref>Eyre, ''Slow Death of a Tropical Rainforest: The Cockpit Country of Jamaica, West Indies,'' 1994</ref> proposed that the Cockpit Country be designated as a [[World Heritage Site]] to preserve its environment. A petition for protection of the area was submitted to Prime Minister [[Bruce Golding]] in 2006.
As of April 2013, public consultations have begun on the definition of the boundary proposed in a recently released study by Mitchell, Miller, Ganapathy, and Spence of the [[University of the West Indies]] (UWI).
''[[Eleutherodactylus sisyphodemus]]'', a small, [[critically endangered]] frog species, is known only from the Cockpit Country.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Hedges, B. | author2 = Koenig, S. | author3 = Wilson, B. | last-author-amp = yes | title = ''Eleutherodactylus sisyphodemus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2004 | page = e.T7148A12831445 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2004 | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/7148/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2004.RLTS.T7148A12831445.en | access-date = 10 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://research.amnh.org/vz/herpetology/amphibia/Amphibia/Anura/Eleutherodactylidae/Eleutherodactylinae/Eleutherodactylus/Eleutherodactylus-sisyphodemus |title=''Eleutherodactylus sisyphodemus'' Crombie, 1977 |author=Frost, Darrel R. |year=2015 |work=Amphibian Species of the World: an Online Reference. Version 6.0 |publisher=American Museum of Natural History |accessdate=18 April 2015}}</ref> Cockpit Country hosts 90% of the global population of [[black-billed amazon]], a parrot [[endemic]] to Jamaica.<ref>{{IUCN|id=22686231 |title=''Amazona agilis'' |assessor=BirdLife International |assessor-link=BirdLife International |version=2013.2 |year=2013 |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>
Cockpit Country is also home to the [[Papilio homerus|Jamaican Swallowtail]], the largest butterfly in the Western hemisphere. Cockpit Country is one of the last remaining homes for the species.
==See also== [[Geography of Jamaica]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://wikimapia.org/#lat=18.2952094&lon=-77.6953125&z=11&l=0&m=b&v=8 Aerial view] * [http://www.jamaicancaves.org/map_cockpit_country_1000.htm Map] * [http://www.jamaicancaves.org/cc-boundary-2008.pdf University of the West Indies (UWI) study on the Cockpit Country boundary]
{{coord|18.2952094|-77.6953125|region:JM-07_type:forest|display=title}}
{{Geography of Jamaica}}
[[Category:Jamaican Maroons]] [[Category:Geography of Trelawny Parish]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Dancon''', an [[abbreviation]] of '''Danish Contingent''', is the term that comprises all [[Denmark|Danish]] national forces in a current military mission of the [[UN]], [[NATO]], or national character. Dancon is not a military unit per se, like a [[brigade]], but rather an organisation in which all [[Military organization#Units, Formations & Commands|military units]] currently working in a mission are linked together. The [[commander]] of Dancon is usually the commander of the hierarchically biggest military unit associated with the specified mission, and does not have a headquarters of its own, but rather it is that military unit's headquarters.
Because several Dancons can exist at the same time, the mission name is usually added to Dancon, like [[Dancon/Irak]] or [[Dancon/SFOR]].
* [[Dancon/UNFICYP]] (early 1964 – 1993) * [[Dancon/UNPROFOR]] (April 1992 – October 1995) * [[Dancon/IFOR]] (December 1995 – December 1996) * [[Dancon/SFOR]] (December 1996 – August 2003) * [[Dancon/Albanien]] (May 1997 - August 1997) * [[Dancon/AFOR]] (June 1999 - September 1999) * [[Dancon/KFOR]] (August 1999 – date) * [[Dancon/UNMEE]] (November 2000 – July 2001) * [[Dancon/ISAF]] (January 2002 – date) * [[Dancon/SRO2]] (March 2002 / Nato-excise [[Strong Resolve]]) * [[Dancon/Irak]] (May 2003 – July 2007) * [[Dancon/ISAF]] (February 2012 – August 2012)
== See also == * [[Dancon March]]
{{Denmark-stub}} [[Category:Military of Denmark]]

'''''Fakta fra verden''''' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] for "Facts from the world") is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[comic strip]] written and drawn by [[Karstein Volle]], since 2001.
The comic has an [[education]]al theme and each episode is written and drawn like an educational message. However, the facts that the strip claims to present are always completely absurd.
==External links== * [http://www.jippicomics.com/butikk/bker-og-album/kors-p-halsen---75-fakta-fra-verden/ ''Fakta fra verden: Kors på halsen'' at Jippi Comics] * [http://www.jippicomics.com/butikk/bker-og-album/med-hnden-p-hjertet--125-fakta-fra-verden/ ''Fakta fra verden: Med hånden på hjertet'' at Jippi Comics]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Gutland | image = Gutland (film).jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Govinda Van Maele]] | producer = Gilles Chanial
Olivier Dubois
Melanie Blocksdorf | writer = Govinda Van Maele | starring = [[Frederick Lau]]
[[Vicky Krieps]] | music = Mocke | cinematography = Narayan Van Maele | editing = Stefan Stabenow | distributor = | released = {{film date|2017|9|8|[[2017 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|df=yes}} | runtime = 107 minutes | country = Luxembourg | language = Luxembourgish
German | budget = €3 million }} '''''Gutland''''' is a 2017 internationally co-produced [[drama film]] directed by [[Govinda Van Maele]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmfund.lu/film-catalogue/films/gutland |title=Gutland |work=Film Fund |date=29 August 2017|accessdate=29 August 2017}} It was screened 8 September 2017 in the Discovery section at the [[2017 Toronto International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/toronto-film-festival-adds-international-films-angelina-jolie-javier-bardem/ |title=Toronto Film Festival Adds International Films, Talks With Angelina Jolie and Javier Bardem |work=[[TheWrap]]|date=22 August 2017|accessdate=28 August 2017 |last=Pond |first=Steve}} In Luxembourg the film was screened for the first time at the [[Luxembourg City Film Festival]] 2018. It was selected as the Luxembourgish entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[91st Academy Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lessentiel.lu/fr/divertissement/cinema/story/gutland-representera-le-luxembourg-aux-oscars-15515664 |title="Gutland" représentera le Luxembourg aux Oscars |work=L'essentiel |date=6 September 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://luxtimes.lu/culture-life/34874-gutland-selected-as-luxembourg-pick-for-oscars |title=Gutland selected as Luxembourg pick for Oscars |work=[[Luxembourg Times]] |first=Hannah |last=Brenton |date=6 September 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}}Abbatescianni, Davide. (10 September 2018). [http://cineuropa.org/en/newsdetail/360064/ Luxembourg pins its hopes on Gutland for the Oscars]. Cineuropa. Retrieved 10 September 2018 ==Cast== * [[Frederick Lau]] as Jens Fauser * [[Vicky Krieps]] as Lucy Loschetter * [[Marco Lorenzini]] as Jos Gierens * [[Pit Bukowski]] as Marcel * [[Leo Folschette]] as Arno Kleyer ==Production== The film, for which a budget of 3 million euros was available, was shot in 37 days during December 2016. It was filmed around Herborn.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wort.lu/de/kultur/stars-in-herborn-vor-der-kamera-gutland-ist-nicht-luxemburg-58469d4a5061e01abe83d4e5|title=Stars in Herborn vor der Kamera: "Gutland" ist nicht Luxemburg|date=6 December 2016|work=Wort.lu|access-date=21 March 2018|language=de}} The film was shot with 35mm.{{Cite news|url=https://www.screendaily.com/reviews/gutland-review/5127518.article|title='Gutland': Review|work=Screen|access-date=21 March 2018|language=en}} The film was inspired in part by Van Maele's experience growing up as the son of immigrant parents in a small Luxembourgish village.{{Cite news|url=https://www.filmdoo.com/blog/2017/11/07/interview-govinda-van-maele-talks-gutland/|title=Interview: Govinda Van Maele talks Gutland|last=|first=|date=7 November 2017|work=FilmDoo|access-date=23 August 2018|language=en-US}} ==Reception== On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 88% based on 8 reviews, and an [[average rating]] of 6/10.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/gutland |title=Gutland (2017) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango Media]] |accessdate=20 March 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 91st Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Luxembourgish submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|5455410|Gutland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gutland}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Luxembourgian films]] [[Category:Luxembourgian drama films]] [[Category:Luxembourgish-language films]] {{Luxembourg-film-stub}} {{2010s-drama-film-stub}}

{{Use American English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat IV F-6 | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = INT4F-6 | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 7 years (planned)
(Launch failure) | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|HS-312]] | spacecraft_type = | manufacturer = [[Hughes Aircraft]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|730|kg|lb}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1414|kg|lb}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|February 20, 1975, 23:35|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 21, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1 AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 36|LC-36A]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = Planned | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_period = | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat IV'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat IV F-5]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat IV F-7]] }} '''Intelsat IV F-6''' was a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] built by [[Hughes Aircraft Company|Hughes]], it was owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the [[Spacebus|HS-312]] platform and its estimated useful life was 7 years. == History == The Intelsat IV F-6 was part of the Intelsat IV series which consisted of eight communications satellites, launched from [[Cape Canaveral]] during the early 1970s, marked the fifth generation of geostationary communications satellites developed by the [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] since 1963 with the launch of Syncom II, the world's first synchronous satellite. The [[Syncom]] II was 15 cm high and 28 inches in diameter, weighing 78 pounds in orbit. In contrast, the Intelsat IVs weighed more than [[Pound (mass)|£]] 1,300 (595 kg) into orbit and were more than 17 feet (5.31 meters) in diameter. All seven satellites exceeded their projected life expectancies and were withdrawn from active duty, the last of which, the [[Intelsat IV F-1]] was retired in October 1987. The satellite was equipped with 12 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] transponders. It had 6,000 two-way [[relay]] phone calls or broadcast 12 concurrent color television programs or mixed combinations of communications traffic including data and fax. The satellite had 12 channels of broadband communication. Each channel had a bandwidth of 40 MHz and provided about 500 communication circuits. == Release == The satellite was lost due to a launcher malfunction{{cite book |last1=Ezell |first1=Linda Neuman |title=NASA Historical Databook |volume=Volume III: Programs and Projects 1969-1978 |publisher=NASA |publication-date=1988-01-01 |at=Table 4-103. Chronology of Intelsat Development and Operations, 1969-1978 |id=NASA-SP-4012-VOL-3 |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4012/vol3/table4.103.htm}}. ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1975 in spaceflight]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1975}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1975]] [[Category:Satellite launch failures]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Radio Station | name = Near FM | airdate = 1995 | frequency = 90.3 [[MHz]] | format = Community | area = Northeast Dublin | owner = Near Media Co-op | website = http://nearfm.ie/ }}
'''Near FM''' (North East Access Radio) 90.3 FM is a [[Broadcasting Authority of Ireland|BAI]]-licensed, communally owned, and not-for-profit community media project.
The project is operated by a democratic co-operative, Near Media Co-op, and is open to all organisations and individuals in [[Dublin]] North-East, [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].
The station provides a wide range of specialist music programmes (blues, punk, ska etc.) as well as a variety of talk programming, incorporating a positive emphasis on facilitating and supporting community development and providing a platform to a wide range of local groups.
Previously known as ''Near fm 101.6'', the station first went on air in August 1995. On Tuesday 23 January 2007, the station switched to a new frequency of 90.3 MHz and was renamed ''Near90fm''. In 2012, the station reverted to using its former ''Near FM'' name.
Near Media Co-op also runs a community television project – Near TV Productions – and an IT project called Near Online. The station also runs an internet cafe in the Northside Civic Centre, [[Coolock]], where the project is based, as well as the Near Drama, Near Records, and Near Choice projects.
Near fm is a founding member of [[CRAOL]], The Community Radio Forum of Ireland.
In the 1980s there was an [[Irish_pirate_radio|pirate radio]] station which NEAR FM is based on called, ''North Dublin Community Radio'' it closed down in order to reform as NEAR FM and apply for a licence.
==Franchise area== Parts of [[Coolock]] including Ayrfield and Kilmore West, [[Artane, Dublin|Artane]], [[Donnycarney]], [[Killester]], [[Kilbarrack]], [[Raheny]], [[Beaumont, Dublin|Beaumont]], [[Baldoyle]], [[Dollymount]], [[Donaghmede]], and [[Darndale]].
==Broadcasting hours== *24 hours a day
==See also==
* [[Phoenix 92.5FM]] * [[Dublin South FM]] * [[Liffey Sound FM]] * [[Raidió na Life]] * [[Raidió Fáilte]] * [[CRAOL]] * [[Broadcasting Authority of Ireland]]
==External links== * [http://www.nearfm.ie Near FM] * [http://near.ie/ Near Media Co-Op] * [https://craol.ie/ CRAOL | The Community Radio Forum of Ireland] * [http://www.bai.ie/ga/ Broadcasting Authority of Ireland / Údarás Craolacháin na hÉireann BAI.]

revision.text:
The '''Police Tribunal''' ({{lang-nl|Politierechtbank}}, {{lang-fr|Tribunal de police}}, {{lang-de|Polizeigericht}}) in [[Belgium]] is a [[court]] which deals with minor offences and infractions, as well as traffic offences and deaths and injuries arising from traffic accidents. In civil cases, it has jurisdiction with regard to claims for compensation related to traffic accidents, irrespective of the amount of the compensation. Decisions of the Police Tribunal can be appealed against to the [[Court of First Instance (Belgium)|Court of First Instance]]. The Police Tribunal also has appellate jurisdiction with regard to the Municipal Administrative Sanctions that [[Municipalities in Belgium|municipalities]] can use to punish certain minor offences since 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presse-justice.be/document.php?document_id=98&lang=nl |title=Politierechtbank |publisher=Pers & Gerecht |accessdate=2007-07-10 |language=Dutch }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presse-justice.be/document.php?document_id=98&lang=fr |title=Le tribunal de police |publisher= Presse & Justice |accessdate=2007-07-10 |language=French }}</ref>
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox political youth organization | name = Republican People's Party Youth | native_name = CHP Gençlik Kolları | colorcode = #FF0000 | logo = | president = Emre Yılmaz | founded = {{Start date|1954}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politikadergisi.com/sites/default/files/kutuphane/turk_siyasi_tarihinde_chpnin_genclik_kollari.pdf |title=Türk Siyasi Tarihi'nde CHP'nin Gençlik Kolları |publisher=Politikadergisi.com |accessdate=2014-02-23}} | ideology = [[Social democracy]]
[[Kemalism]] | headquarters = [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]] | mother party = [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] | international = [[International Union of Socialist Youth]] | regional1_type = European | regional1_name = [[Young European Socialists]] | national = | website = [http://www.chpgenclikkollari.org.tr/ chpgenclikkollari.org.tr] }} '''Republican People's Party Youth''' (also known as '''CHP Youth''') ({{lang-tr|Cumhuriyet Halk Partisi Gençlik Kolları or CHP Gençlik Kolları}}) is the [[youth organization]] of the [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] in [[Turkey]]. The organization has been a member of [[International Union of Socialist Youth]] since 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.iusy.org/en/about-us/members/members-overview |accessdate=August 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421081629/http://www.iusy.org/en/about-us/members/members-overview |archivedate=April 21, 2013|title=IUSY }} and [[Young European Socialists]] since 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.chp.org.tr/?p=18588 |title=CHP Gençlik Kolları, Avrupa Sosyalist Gençlik Örgütü’ne oybirliği ile kabul edildi |publisher=Chp.org.tr |date= |accessdate=2014-02-24}} They hosted the [[Young European Socialists|YES]] Summer Camp 2013 in [[Foça]], [[İzmir]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youngsocialists.eu/yes-summer-camp-2013-statement-on-the-current-situation-in-turkey |title=YES Summer Camp 2013 – Statement on the current situation in Turkey : Young European Socialists (YES) |publisher=Youngsocialists.eu |date=2013-08-19 |accessdate=2014-02-24}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official|http://www.chpgenclik.com/ }} {{YES member organisations}} {{DEFAULTSORT:CHP Genclik Kollari}} [[Category:Republican People's Party (Turkey)]] [[Category:Youth wings of political parties in Turkey]] [[Category:Youth wings of social democratic parties]] [[Category:Secularism in Turkey]] [[Category:Youth organizations established in 1954]] [[Category:Republicanism in Turkey]] {{Turkey-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Schistosomiasis Control Initiative | logo = File:Schistosomiasis Control Initiative logo.jpg | type = Non-profit | genre = [[Medical logistics]], supporting and evaluating treatment programmes against schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminthiasis. | foundation = {{Start date and age|2002}} | homepage = {{URL|www.schisto.org}} | location = [[Imperial College London]] | location_city = [[London]] | location_country = [[United Kingdom]] | area_served = Sub-Saharan Africa and Yemen | key_people = Professor Alan Fenwick OBE (Founder), Dr Wendy Harrison (Executive Director), Dr Lynsey Blair (Implementation Director), Dr Fiona Fleming (Monitoring, Evaluation & Research Director), Najwa Al-Abdallah (Finance & Operations Director) | num_employees = 28 }}'''The Schistosomiasis Control Initiative (SCI)''', at Imperial College London, is a non-profit initiative that works with Ministries of Health in sub-Saharan African countries and Yemen. It supports and evaluates treatment programmes against [[schistosomiasis]] and [[Soil-transmitted helminthiasis|soil-transmitted helminthiasis (STH).]]
These parasitic infections are part of a group called “Neglected Tropical Diseases”, which affect the poorest and most marginalised communities in the world. They can impair a child’s development, reduce school attendance and productivity, and even cause internal organ damage.
Estimates suggest that over 1 billion people are infected by these diseases. However, treatment is safe, effective and can reverse the damaging effects of infections, and costs as little as £1 for three people. In fact, the SCI has been recommended by the charity evaluator [https://www.givewell.org/ GiveWell], as one of the world’s most cost-effective non-profits to receive donations.
The impact of SCI-supported treatment programmes is observed quickly. The number of people infected by these parasites can be reduced by up to 60% after the first round of treatment and sustained below 11% after two rounds of treatment.
SCI continually conducts research to assess programme performance and investigate novel approaches to disease management. This ensures that control strategies are optimised and will ultimately lead to disease elimination.
==History<ref>http://www.imperial.ac.uk/schistosomiasis-control-initiative/about</ref>== In 2002, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundations Global Health Programme granted a £20 million award to establish the SCI at Imperial College London. SCI assisted the Ministries of Health and Education to deliver treatment for schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminthiasis in 6 countries, targeting school-aged children and adults at high risk of infection.
In 2006, the SCI was a founding partner of the [[Global Network for Neglected Tropical Diseases]] which promoted integration of control or elimination programmes against seven NTDs.
By 2007, the SCI had facilitated delivery of approximately 40 million treatments of [[praziquantel]] against schistosomiasis, and many more deworming doses of [[albendazole]].
In 2010, SCI expanded its reach after the award of the management of [http://www.imperial.ac.uk/schistosomiasis-control-initiative/our-work/projects/ ICOSA] - a programme funded by the Department for International Development (DFID). ICOSA delivered 203 million treatments against schistosomiasis and STH in 10 sub-Saharan African countries by December 2018.
In April 2013, SCI announced that it had facilitated delivery of its [http://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/121788/imperial-group-reaches-milestone-tropical-disease/ 100 millionth treatment of praziquantel against schistosomiasis] thanks to funding from private donations which complemented the ICOSA award.
By 2016, SCI had reached an annual delivery of over 50 million treatments for schistosomiasis and STH.

{{nowrap|{{flagdeco|Somalia}} [[Somali Democratic Republic|Somalia]] (until 1991){{citation needed|date=June 2018}}}} |opponents = {{flag|Ethiopia}} |battles = |website = {{Official website|www.sidamanationalliberationfront.org/}} }} The '''Sidama Liberation Front''' ([[Abbreviation|abbreviated]] '''SLF''') is an active rebel group in the [[Sidama Zone]] in [[Ethiopia]].{{cite web|title=UNPO: Asmara Hosts the First Congress of PAFD|url=http://unpo.org/article/19049|website=unpo.org|accessdate=12 May 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|title=UNPO: Urgency of Addressing the Plight of Women Belonging to Vulnerable Groups in Ethiopia Highlighted at UNPO EP Conference|url=http://unpo.org/article/19975|website=unpo.org|accessdate=12 May 2017|language=en}} It is allied with two other rebel groups, the [[Ogaden National Liberation Front]] and the [[Oromo Liberation Front]], and is fighting against the government of Ethiopia for the [[self-determination]] of the [[Sidama people]].{{cite web|title=About Sidama Liberation Front|url=http://sidamanationalliberationfront.org/About%20SLF.html|accessdate=9 December 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Guerrilla organizations]] [[Category:National liberation movements in Africa]] [[Category:Rebel groups in Ethiopia]] {{Paramilitary-org-stub}} {{Ethiopia-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = The Egyptian Starch, Yeast and Detergents
المصرية للنشا و الخميرة و المنظفات | logo = [[Image:Egy SYD Logo.png#file|120px]] | type = [[Government-owned corporation]] | foundation = 1927 | location_city = 21 Abu Soliman Street, El Siouf, [[Alexandria Governorate|Alexandria]] | location_country = [[Egypt]] | key_people = Mohamed Nabeel (Chairman & Ceo.) | industry = [[Detergents]], [[Food industry]] | products = Rice Starch product, Yeast products and Detergents products | owner = Holding company for food industries | num_employees = 1187 Employees | divisions = Starch Factories, Yeast Factories and Detergents Factories. | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.egysyd.com/}} }} '''The Egyptian Starch, Yeast and Detergents''' is an [[Egypt]]ian company specializing in producing of [[Rice]] [[Starch]], [[Baking]] [[Yeast]] and Detergents. It was established in 1927 during Egypt’s nationalization program as The Egyptian Starch and Yeast, which has been the country’s main provider with 86% of market share of [[baking]] [[yeast]], [[starch]] and confectionery at that time. ==References== {{reflist}} * [http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=20881214 Bloomberg Businessweek] * [http://eg.kompass.com/live/en/EG010135/egyptian-starch-yeast-detergents.html#.UoEiOnBmyo0 Kompass] ==External links== * [http://www.egysyd.com/ Official website] {{-}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Egyptian Starch, Yeast and Detergents Co}} [[Category:Food companies of Egypt]] [[Category:Food and drink companies established in 1927]] [[Category:Chemical companies established in 1927]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Egypt]] [[Category:Government-owned companies of Egypt]] [[Category:Alexandria]] {{food-company-stub}} {{Egypt-company-stub}}

{{use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The Garden (Záhrada) | director = [[Martin Šulík]] | writer = Marek Leščák
Ondrej Šulaj
Martin Šulík | starring = [[Marián Labuda]]
[[Roman Luknár]]
[[Zuzana Šulajová]]
[[Jana Švandová]]
Katarína Vrzalová | music = [[Vladimír Godár]] | cinematography = [[Martin Štrba]] | distributor = Action Gitanes | released = {{Film date|1995|6|15|df=y}} | runtime = 99 minutes | country = Slovakia
France
Czech Republic{{cite web|last1=s.r.o.|first1=LaTaupe|title=Zahrada|url=http://www.infilm.cz/cs/filmy/zahrada.html|website=www.infilm.cz|accessdate=11 April 2018|language=cs}} | language = Slovak }} '''''The Garden''''' ({{lang-sk|'''Záhrada'''}}) is a 1995 Slovak feature film in cooperation with French Artcam International and Czech InFilm Praha directed by [[Martin Šulík]]. The film is a poetic tale of Jakub, a man in his early 30s. It reflects the relationships and desires of Jakub in the idyllic surroundings of his grandfather's garden. The film was selected as the Slovak entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[68th Academy Awards]], but was not accepted as a nominee.Margaret Herrick Library, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences{{Cite web|url=http://www.filmfestivals.com/news/newsl1.htm |title=41 to Compete for Foreign Language Oscar Nominations |accessdate=4 October 2015 |work=FilmFestivals.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407001102/http://www.filmfestivals.com/news/newsl1.htm |archivedate=7 April 2012 }} ==Plot== Jakub is a daydreamer in his early 30s and is still living with his father. The father is tired of Jakub's idleness and throws him out of the flat. He tells Jakub to sell the old garden of his grandfather and to buy his own flat. Jakub retires into the neglected garden and retreats into the worn garden house from the world and from his problems. The garden turns out to be a magical place full of surprises and mysteries. Jakub stumbles across his grandfather’s journal which is written in reverse script. He finds a map leading him to an old bottle of slivovice hidden years ago. Now curious Jakub must solve the mysteries of his grandfather’s garden. He meets Helena, a young girl Jakub’s grandfather taught to also write backwards. Strange things happen in the garden, and some of them do indeed seem like miracles. Amid the eccentric events, young Helena teaches Jakub to appreciate the delicate mysteries of life. In the end Jakub loses all his possessions but finds his peace. ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Actor !! Role |- | [[Marián Labuda]] || Jakub's father |- | [[Roman Luknár]] || Jakub |- | [[Zuzana Šulajová]] || Helena |- | [[Jana Švandová]] || Tereza |- | Katarína Vrzalová || Helena's mother |} ==Reception== ''The Garden'' is one of the most recognised films of post communist [[Slovakia]]. It is especially popular in Slovakia and the [[Czech Republic]]. It won the [[Special Jury Prize (Karlovy Vary IFF)|Special Jury Prize]] at the 40th [[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival]] in 1995, and several [[Czech Lion]]s in 1996. ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 68th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Slovak submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0115040|The Garden}} {{CzechLionBestFilm}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garden}} [[Category:1995 films]] [[Category:1995 in Slovakia]] [[Category:Films directed by Martin Šulík]] [[Category:Czech films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Slovak films]] [[Category:Slovak-language films]] [[Category:Czech Lion Awards winners (films)]] {{Slovakia-film-stub}}

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-38 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1989-044A | SATCAT = 20061 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block II]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|840|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|10 June 1989, 22:19|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II|Delta II 6925]],}} D185 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|12 May 2004}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19967|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20395|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.5 degrees | orbit_period = 717.92 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-38''', also known as '''GPS II-2''' and '''GPS SVN-13''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which formed part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the second of nine [[GPS Block II|Block II]] GPS satellites to be launched, which were the first operational GPS satellites to be launched. USA-38 was launched at 22:19 UTC on 10 June 1989, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D185, flying in the 6925 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-38 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2.htm|title=GPS-2 (Navstar-2)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 11 July 1989, USA-38 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19967|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20395|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.92 minutes, and 54.5 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It operated in slot 3 of plane B of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.spaceandtech.com/spacedata/constellations/navstar-gps_consum.shtml|title=NAVSTAR GPS - Summary|publisher=Space and Tech|accessdate=10 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120615061419/http://www.spaceandtech.com/spacedata/constellations/navstar-gps_consum.shtml|archivedate=15 June 2012|df=}} The satellite had a mass of {{convert|840|kg}}, and generated 710 watts of power.{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1989-044A|title=Navstar 2-02|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It had a design life of 7.5 years, and ceased operations on 12 May 2004. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1989}} [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1989]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
